Mexican Holidays & Festivals Guide

Celebrate with Mexico Year-Round

Last updated: January 2025

Mexico celebrates with unmatched passion. From the profound traditions of Day of the Dead to raucous Independence Day parties, from indigenous festivals unchanged for centuries to modern music festivals, there's always something to celebrate. This guide covers the major holidays and festivals to help you plan your visit—or know what to expect if you're traveling during these times.

In This Guide

  • Day of the Dead (Día de los Muertos)
  • Independence Day (Día de la Independencia)
  • Semana Santa (Holy Week / Easter)
  • Guelaguetza (Oaxaca)
  • Day of the Virgin of Guadalupe
  • Christmas & New Year (Navidad y Año Nuevo)
  • Carnaval (Carnival)
  • Cinco de Mayo
  • Regional Festivals Calendar
  • Music & Cultural Festivals
  • Planning Around Holidays

Day of the Dead (Día de los Muertos)

{<strong>When:</strong> October 31 - November 2</p><p><strong>What:</strong> Mexico's most iconic celebration honors deceased loved ones who are believed to return each year. Families build altars (ofrendas) with photos, favorite foods, marigolds, and candles. Cemetery vigils last through the night.</p><p><strong>Where to Experience:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Oaxaca</strong> — The spiritual heart, with comparsas (parades), elaborate altars, and profound cemetery vigils</p><ul><li><strong>Pátzcuaro, Michoacán</strong> — Island cemetery vigils on Janitzio with indigenous Purépecha traditions</p><ul><li><strong>Mixquic, CDMX</strong> — Candlelit cemetery famous for its atmosphere</p><ul><li><strong>Mexico City</strong> — Massive parade on Reforma, citywide altars and events</p><p><strong>Planning Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Book hotels 6+ months ahead—this is peak season</p><ul><li>Prices surge significantly</p><ul><li>Nov 1 honors deceased children (angelitos), Nov 2 honors adults</p><ul><li>Be respectful at cemeteries—you're witnessing private grief in public</p><p><strong>Cultural Note:</strong> This is NOT Mexican Halloween. It's a profound tradition about accepting death as part of life and maintaining connection with ancestors.}

Independence Day (Día de la Independencia)

{<strong>When:</strong> September 15-16</p><p><strong>What:</strong> Mexico's biggest patriotic celebration commemorates the 1810 cry for independence (El Grito). The president reenacts the Grito from the National Palace at 11pm on September 15, followed by fireworks and all-night partying.</p><p><strong>Where to Experience:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Mexico City</strong> — The Zócalo fills with hundreds of thousands for the official ceremony</p><ul><li><strong>Guanajuato</strong> — Where the revolution began, deeply significant celebrations</p><ul><li><strong>Dolores Hidalgo</strong> — The actual town where the Grito was first shouted</p><ul><li><strong>Every town in Mexico</strong> — Local plazas replicate the ceremony</p><p><strong>What Happens:</strong></p><ul><li>Sept 15: El Grito ceremony at 11pm, fireworks, parties continue all night</p><ul><li>Sept 16: Official holiday, parades, family gatherings, patriotic events</p><p><strong>Planning Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Great time to visit if you want to celebrate</p><ul><li>Hotels in popular destinations book up</p><ul><li>Public transportation packed around the Zócalo</p><ul><li>Mexicans take this seriously—it's their Fourth of July</p><p><strong>Food:</strong> Chiles en nogada (poblano peppers in walnut sauce with pomegranate) is the seasonal dish—its colors represent the Mexican flag.}

Semana Santa (Holy Week / Easter)

{<strong>When:</strong> Week before Easter (March-April, dates vary)</p><p><strong>What:</strong> Mexico's biggest vacation week. Devout Catholics observe religious processions, while most Mexicans head to beaches and resorts. The country essentially shuts down.</p><p><strong>Religious Observances:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>San Miguel de Allende</strong> — Silent processions, elaborate carpets of flowers and sawdust</p><ul><li><strong>Taxco</strong> — Dramatic processions with penitents, self-flagellation (intense)</p><ul><li><strong>Oaxaca</strong> — Traditional observances with indigenous elements</p><ul><li><strong>Pátzcuaro</strong> — Processions around the lake</p><p><strong>Beach Madness:</strong></p><ul><li>Cancún, Puerto Vallarta, Acapulco, Los Cabos fill with Mexican families</p><ul><li>Prices peak, hotels sell out months ahead</p><ul><li>Beaches are crowded but festive</p><p><strong>Planning Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>If you want peace and quiet, AVOID Semana Santa</p><ul><li>If you want cultural experience, attend processions in colonial towns</p><ul><li>Book months ahead or accept high prices</p><ul><li>Banks, businesses, government offices closed</p><ul><li>Traffic horrific traveling anywhere Thursday-Monday}

Guelaguetza (Oaxaca)

{<strong>When:</strong> Last two Mondays of July</p><p><strong>What:</strong> Oaxaca's greatest festival—a massive celebration of indigenous culture with traditional dance, music, costumes, and food from all seven regions of Oaxaca state. Thousands perform in the hillside amphitheater.</p><p><strong>What to Expect:</strong></p><ul><li>Performances at the Cerro del Fortín amphitheater (main event)</p><ul><li>Delegations from indigenous communities perform traditional dances in full regalia</p><ul><li>Performers throw gifts to the audience (fruit, crafts, bread)</p><ul><li>Street parades, mezcal flowing, regional food everywhere</p><p><strong>Where:</strong> Oaxaca City (events throughout the city and surrounding villages)</p><p><strong>Planning Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Book accommodation 4-6 months ahead</p><ul><li>Official tickets sell out fast—buy through official channels to avoid scams</p><ul><li>Free events happen throughout the city all week</p><ul><li>Consider staying the full week for the complete experience</p><p><strong>Cost:</strong> Amphitheater tickets: Free (limited) to $800+ MXN for good seats. Tours and packages available.}

Day of the Virgin of Guadalupe

{<strong>When:</strong> December 12 (celebrations begin December 11)</p><p><strong>What:</strong> Mexico's most important religious celebration honors the patron saint. Millions pilgrimage to the Basilica of Guadalupe in Mexico City—the most visited Catholic site in the world after the Vatican.</p><p><strong>What Happens:</strong></p><ul><li>Pilgrims walk (some crawl on their knees) to the Basilica</p><ul><li>Indigenous groups perform traditional dances outside the church</p><ul><li>Midnight Mass on December 11-12 is the climax</p><ul><li>Celebrations in every church and town across Mexico</p><p><strong>Where:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Mexico City</strong> — The Basilica receives 5-10 million visitors in the days around Dec 12</p><ul><li><strong>Every town</strong> — Local churches hold processions and celebrations</p><p><strong>Planning Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>The area around the Basilica is extremely crowded Dec 10-12</p><ul><li>Amazing cultural experience if you go with the flow</p><ul><li>Early morning December 12 is powerful (post-midnight Mass atmosphere)</p><ul><li>Traffic in northern CDMX is impossible}

Christmas & New Year (Navidad y Año Nuevo)

{<strong>When:</strong> December 16 - January 6</p><p><strong>What:</strong> Extended holiday season beginning with Las Posadas (nine nights of processions reenacting Mary and Joseph's journey) and continuing through Three Kings Day.</p><p><strong>Key Dates:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dec 16-24:</strong> Las Posadas processions nightly</p><ul><li><strong>Dec 24 (Nochebuena):</strong> Main celebration—family dinner, midnight Mass</p><ul><li><strong>Dec 25:</strong> Quiet family day, gifts for children</p><ul><li><strong>Dec 31 (Año Nuevo):</strong> Parties, 12 grapes at midnight for luck</p><ul><li><strong>Jan 6 (Día de Reyes):</strong> Three Kings Day—traditional gift day for children, rosca de reyes cake</p><p><strong>Where to Experience:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>San Miguel de Allende</strong> — Beautiful posadas, colonial atmosphere</p><ul><li><strong>Oaxaca</strong> — Radish Night (Noche de Rábanos) Dec 23 with carved radish sculptures</p><ul><li><strong>Any small town</strong> — Community posadas are welcoming</p><p><strong>Planning Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Many businesses close Dec 24-25, some until Jan 2</p><ul><li>Resorts and tourist areas stay open but at premium prices</p><ul><li>Mexican families prioritize Nochebuena over Dec 25</p><ul><li>Great time to experience family-oriented Mexican culture}

Carnaval (Carnival)

{<strong>When:</strong> Week before Lent (February-March, dates vary)</p><p><strong>What:</strong> Mexico's pre-Lenten celebration varies by region—some rival Rio for spectacle.</p><p><strong>Best Carnavales:</strong></p><p><strong>Mazatlán:</strong></p><ul><li>One of world's largest Carnavales</p><ul><li>Massive parades, floats, concerts</p><ul><li>Beach party atmosphere</p><ul><li>Comparible to New Orleans Mardi Gras</p><p><strong>Veracruz:</strong></p><ul><li>Caribbean-influenced, music-heavy</p><ul><li>Nine days of parades and dancing</p><ul><li>Danzón and son jarocho music</p><ul><li>Considered most traditional</p><p><strong>Mérida:</strong></p><ul><li>More refined, Yucatecan flavor</p><ul><li>Regional music and dance</p><ul><li>Less crowded than Mazatlán</p><p><strong>Cozumel:</strong></p><ul><li>Smaller but colorful</p><ul><li>Island party atmosphere</p><p><strong>Planning Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Book early—hotel prices spike</p><ul><li>Embrace the chaos</p><ul><li>Great for music and dancing lovers</p><ul><li>Family-friendly during the day, adult party at night}

Cinco de Mayo

{<strong>When:</strong> May 5</p><p><strong>What:</strong> Commemorates Mexico's victory over French forces at the Battle of Puebla in 1862. Contrary to popular belief, it's NOT Mexican Independence Day and is a relatively minor holiday in most of Mexico.</p><p><strong>Reality Check:</strong></p><ul><li>Much bigger celebration in the USA than in Mexico</p><ul><li>Not a national holiday (banks and businesses open)</p><ul><li>Primarily celebrated in Puebla state</p><p><strong>Where to Experience:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Puebla</strong> — Parades, reenactments, civic ceremonies</p><ul><li>The rest of Mexico mostly ignores it</p><p><strong>Planning Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Don't plan a trip around Cinco de Mayo expecting big celebrations</p><ul><li>If in Puebla, enjoy the local festivities</p><ul><li>Good day to visit Puebla and learn the actual history}

Regional Festivals Calendar

{<strong>January:</strong></p><ul><li>New Year's Day (Jan 1) — National holiday</p><ul><li>Three Kings Day (Jan 6) — Gift giving, rosca de reyes</p><ul><li>San Sebastian Festival, San Cristóbal de las Casas (around Jan 20)</p><p><strong>February:</strong></p><ul><li>Constitution Day (Feb 5) — National holiday</p><ul><li>Carnaval (varies) — Mazatlán, Veracruz, Cozumel</p><ul><li>Flag Day (Feb 24)</p><p><strong>March:</strong></p><ul><li>Spring Equinox at Chichén Itzá (Mar 20-21) — Serpent shadow descends the pyramid</p><ul><li>Vernal Equinox celebrations, Teotihuacán</p><p><strong>March-April:</strong></p><ul><li>Semana Santa (varies) — National vacation week</p><p><strong>April-May:</strong></p><ul><li>Feria de San Marcos, Aguascalientes (April-May) — Mexico's largest state fair</p><p><strong>May:</strong></p><ul><li>Labor Day (May 1) — National holiday</p><ul><li>Cinco de Mayo (May 5) — Battle of Puebla commemoration</p><ul><li>Mother's Day (May 10) — HUGE in Mexico, restaurants packed</p><p><strong>June:</strong></p><ul><li>Navy Day (Jun 1)</p><ul><li>Corpus Christi (varies) — Traditional celebrations</p><p><strong>July:</strong></p><ul><li>Guelaguetza, Oaxaca (last two Mondays)</p><p><strong>August:</strong></p><ul><li>Assumption of Mary (Aug 15)</p><p><strong>September:</strong></p><ul><li>Independence Day (Sep 15-16) — Major national celebration</p><ul><li>International Mariachi Festival, Guadalajara (late Aug/early Sep)</p><p><strong>October:</strong></p><ul><li>Día de la Raza (Oct 12) — Day of the Race/Indigenous Peoples Day</p><ul><li>Cervantino Festival, Guanajuato (Oct) — Major arts festival</p><ul><li>Start of Day of the Dead preparations (late Oct)</p><p><strong>November:</strong></p><ul><li>Day of the Dead (Nov 1-2) — Major celebration</p><ul><li>Revolution Day (Nov 20) — National holiday</p><p><strong>December:</strong></p><ul><li>Virgin of Guadalupe (Dec 12) — Major religious celebration</p><ul><li>Las Posadas (Dec 16-24)</p><ul><li>Christmas (Dec 24-25)</p><ul><li>New Year's Eve (Dec 31)}

Music & Cultural Festivals

{<strong>Cervantino Festival (Guanajuato)</strong></p><ul><li><strong>When:</strong> October (2-3 weeks)</p><ul><li><strong>What:</strong> Latin America's largest arts festival. Theater, music, dance, visual arts in this stunning colonial city.</p><ul><li><strong>Why Go:</strong> World-class performances in magical settings—plazas, theaters, churches.</p><p><strong>Festival Internacional de Cine de Morelia</strong></p><ul><li><strong>When:</strong> October</p><ul><li><strong>What:</strong> Mexico's premier film festival. Mexican and international films.</p><ul><li><strong>Why Go:</strong> See Mexico's film industry celebrated in a beautiful colonial city.</p><p><strong>Jazz Festival, Riviera Maya</strong></p><ul><li><strong>When:</strong> November-December</p><ul><li><strong>What:</strong> International jazz acts on Caribbean beaches.</p><ul><li><strong>Why Go:</strong> Great music in paradise setting.</p><p><strong>Cumbre Tajín (Papantla, Veracruz)</strong></p><ul><li><strong>When:</strong> March</p><ul><li><strong>What:</strong> Music festival at the ancient El Tajín pyramids. Totonac culture meets modern music.</p><ul><li><strong>Why Go:</strong> Unique combination of archaeology and music.</p><p><strong>Corona Capital (Mexico City)</strong></p><ul><li><strong>When:</strong> November</p><ul><li><strong>What:</strong> Major rock/indie music festival at Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez.</p><ul><li><strong>Why Go:</strong> Big international acts, great Mexican bands.</p><p><strong>Vive Latino (Mexico City)</strong></p><ul><li><strong>When:</strong> March</p><ul><li><strong>What:</strong> Latin America's largest rock festival.</p><ul><li><strong>Why Go:</strong> Latin rock, indie, electronic music.}

Planning Around Holidays

{<strong>When to Embrace Festivals:</strong></p><ul><li>You want cultural immersion</p><ul><li>You don't mind crowds</p><ul><li>You book well in advance</p><ul><li>You're flexible with higher prices</p><p><strong>When to Avoid:</strong></p><ul><li>You want quiet and solitude</p><ul><li>You're on a tight budget</p><ul><li>You're booking last-minute</p><ul><li>You need to conduct business</p><p><strong>Booking Lead Times:</strong></p><ul><li>Day of the Dead in Oaxaca: 6+ months</p><ul><li>Semana Santa beach resorts: 3-4 months</p><ul><li>Independence Day in CDMX: 2-3 months</p><ul><li>Guelaguetza: 4-6 months</p><ul><li>Christmas/New Year: 3-4 months</p><p><strong>Business Considerations:</strong></p><ul><li>Government offices close on official holidays</p><ul><li>Banks closed: New Year, Constitution Day, Benito Juárez Birthday (Mar 21), Labor Day, Independence Day, Revolution Day, Christmas</p><ul><li>Semana Santa: Many businesses close entire week</p><ul><li>December: Reduced hours, many take vacation Dec 20 - Jan 6</p><p><strong>Transportation:</strong></p><ul><li>Bus and flight prices surge around major holidays</p><ul><li>Book transport 2-4 weeks ahead during holiday periods</p><ul><li>Traffic is horrific leaving/entering cities around Semana Santa and long weekends}

Frequently Asked Questions

What is Mexico's biggest holiday?

Independence Day (September 15-16) and Day of the Dead (November 1-2) are the two biggest celebrations. Independence Day is more universally celebrated with parties and patriotism, while Day of the Dead is more culturally significant and varies by region. Semana Santa (Easter week) causes the biggest travel disruption as the entire country goes on vacation.

Is Cinco de Mayo a big deal in Mexico?

No! Cinco de Mayo is much bigger in the United States than in Mexico. It commemorates a battle victory in 1862 and is mainly celebrated in Puebla state. It's not even a national holiday—banks and businesses stay open. Mexican Independence Day is September 16, not May 5.

When should I avoid traveling to Mexico?

Avoid Semana Santa (Easter week) unless you want crowds and premium prices—the entire country vacations at once. Christmas through New Year is busy and expensive at resorts. These are great times to visit if you embrace the festivity, but terrible for budget travelers or those seeking solitude.

What's the best festival to experience Mexican culture?

Day of the Dead in Oaxaca or Pátzcuaro offers the deepest cultural immersion—you witness ancient traditions honoring ancestors with altars, vigils, and celebrations. Guelaguetza (July, Oaxaca) showcases indigenous culture through dance and music. Independence Day captures Mexican patriotism and party spirit.

How far ahead should I book for Day of the Dead?

Book hotels 6+ months ahead for Oaxaca or Pátzcuaro during Day of the Dead (late October-early November). This is peak season with peak prices. Flights also fill up. Even Mexico City hotels near cemeteries book out. It's Mexico's most popular tourist event for a reason.
